018package org.opengis.filter;
019
020import java.util.List;
021import java.util.function.Predicate;
022import org.opengis.util.CodeList;
023import org.opengis.feature.Feature;
024import org.opengis.feature.FeatureType;
025import org.opengis.annotation.UML;
026import org.opengis.annotation.Classifier;
027import org.opengis.annotation.Stereotype;
028
029import static org.opengis.annotation.Specification.ISO_19143;
030
031
032/**
033 * Identification of a subset of resources from a collection of resources
034 * whose property values satisfy a set of logically connected predicates.
035 * Often a filter is used to define a set of {@link Feature} instances that are to be operated upon.
036 * The operating set can be comprised of one or more enumerated features or a set of features defined by
037 * specifying spatial and non-spatial constraints on the geometric and scalar properties of a {@link FeatureType}.
038 *
039 * <p>Roughly speaking, a filter encodes the information present in the {@code WHERE} clause of a SQL statement.
040 * There are various sub-interfaces of this interface that represent many types of filters,
041 * such as simple property comparisons or spatial queries.</p>
042 *
043 * <p>The second use of {@code Filter} focuses on expressing constraints (or Facets).
044 * This use places restrictions on the allowable and is captured as part of schema information {@link FeatureType}.
045 * This is similar to the XML concept of "facets".</p>
046 *
047 * <h2>Parameter types</h2>
048 * Filters are typically used for filtering feature instances.
049 * In such case, the {@code <R>} type parameter should be {@link org.opengis.feature.Feature}.
050 * However it is legal to use filters for other kinds of resources, for example coverage's geometry-value pairs.
051 * The latter are sometime considered as a kind of features.
052 *
053 * <p>The value of {@code <? super R>} can be obtained at runtime by a call to {@link #getResourceClass()}.</p>
054 *
055 * @author  Chris Dillard (SYS Technologies)
056 * @author  Martin Desruisseaux (Geomatys)
057 * @version 3.1
058 * @since   3.1
059 *
060 * @param  <R>  the type of resources (e.g. {@link org.opengis.feature.Feature}) to filter.
061 *
062 * @departure easeOfUse
063 *   In ISO specification, {@code Filter} contains a "filter" property of type {@code Operator}.
064 *   Then various {@code Operator} subclasses are provided such as {@code SpatialOperator}, <i>etc.</i>
065 *   GeoAPI removes this indirection level and extends {@code Filter} directly instead.
066 */
067@Classifier(Stereotype.ABSTRACT)
068@UML(identifier="Filter", specification=ISO_19143)
069public interface Filter<R> extends Predicate<R> {
070    /**
071     * A filter that always evaluates to {@code true}.
072     * This is a placeholder for meaning "no filtering".
073     * Filtering a set with {@code Filter.INCLUDE} results in the original set.
074     *
075     * <table class="ogc">
076     *   <caption>Use with logic operators</caption>
077     *   <tr><th>Operation</th> <th>Result</th></tr>
078     *   <tr><td>{@code INCLUDE} or  Filter</td> <td>{@code INCLUDE}</td></tr>
079     *   <tr><td>{@code INCLUDE} and Filter</td> <td>Filter</td></tr>
080     *   <tr><td>not {@code INCLUDE}</td> <td>{@link #exclude EXCLUDE}</td></tr>
081     * </table>
082     *
083     * @param  <R>  the type of resources to filter.
084     * @return the "no filtering" filter.
085     */
086    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
087    static <R> Filter<R> include() {
088        return FilterLiteral.INCLUDE;
089    }
090
091    /**
092     * A filter that always evaluates to {@code false}.
093     * Filtering a set with {@code Filter.EXCLUDE} results in the empty set.
094     *
095     * <table class="ogc">
096     *   <caption>Use with logic operators</caption>
097     *   <tr><th>Operation</th> <th>Result</th></tr>
098     *   <tr><td>{@code EXCLUDE} or  Filter</td> <td>Filter</td></tr>
099     *   <tr><td>{@code EXCLUDE} and Filter</td> <td>{@code EXCLUDE}</td></tr>
100     *   <tr><td>not {@code EXCLUDE}</td> <td>{@link #include INCLUDE}</td></tr>
101     * </table>
102     *
103     * @param  <R>  the type of resources to filter.
104     * @return the "exclude all" filter.
105     */
106    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
107    static <R> Filter<R> exclude() {
108        return FilterLiteral.EXCLUDE;
109    }
110
111    /**
112     * Returns the nature of the operator. The code list can be {@link LogicalOperatorName},
113     * {@link SpatialOperatorName}, {@link DistanceOperatorName} or {@link TemporalOperatorName}
114     * depending on the {@code Filter} sub-interface.
115     *
116     * @return the nature of this operator.
117     *
118     * @departure generalization
119     *   The ISO/OGC standard defines an {@code operatorType} property in {@code UnaryLogicOperator},
120     *   {@code BinaryLogicOperator}, {@link BinaryComparisonOperator}, {@link BinarySpatialOperator}
121     *   and {@link DistanceOperator}. This method has been added for providing a single access point
122     *   for that information without the need to check for each sub-type.
123     */
124    CodeList<?> getOperatorType();
125
126    /**
127     * Returns the class of resources expected by this filter. This is the runtime value of the {@code <R>} type,
128     * except that some implementations may accept instances of a more generic type such as {@code Object.class}.
129     * For example {@link #include()} and {@link #exclude()} put no restriction on the resource type
130     * because those filters ignore the given resource.
131     *
132     * <h4>Implementation note</h4>
133     * This filter resource class should be assignable to all resource classes expected by
134     * the {@linkplain #getExpressions() expressions} that are arguments of this filter.
135     * The type parametrization rules guarantee that at least one such specialized class exists: {@code <R>}.
136     * The behavior of this method is undefined if compile-time type safety was bypassed with unchecked casts,
137     * resulting in possible inconsistencies in the tree of expressions.
138     * The undefined behavior may be throwing an exception or returning {@code null}.
139     *
140     * @return type of resources accepted by this filter.
141     *
142     * @see Expression#getResourceClass()
143     */
144    Class<? super R> getResourceClass();
145
146    /**
147     * Returns the expressions used as arguments for this filter.
148     * This method shall return all parameters used directly by the filter,
149     * including the ones also available by dedicated methods
150     * (possibly as {@linkplain Literal literals}).
151     *
152     * @return the expressions used as inputs, or an empty list if none.
153     *
154     * @departure generalization
155     *   This method has been added for providing a single access point for information provided in sub-types.
156     *   The properties captured here have different names in OGC/ISO specification depending on the sub-type:
157     *   {@code expression} (with a cardinality of 1, 2 or unlimited), {@code operand1}, {@code operand2}, or
158     *   {@code valueReference}. This method provides a way to access those expressions without the need to
159     *   make special cases for each sub-type.
160     */
161    List<Expression<R,?>> getExpressions();
162    /*
163     * API design note: the `<R>` parameterized type could be more generic. It could be `<? super R>` instead.
164     * However expressions and filters are often chained, and following a chain of filters become difficult if,
165     * when asking parameters of parameters, the `<? super R>` type become a kind of `<? super ? super R>` type.
166     * The latter is reported by the compiler as `<? super #CAP1>`. Experience with implementation shows that it
167     * is difficult to avoid unsafe cast in such cases.
168     */
169
170    /**
171     * Given an object, determines if the test(s) represented by this filter are passed.
172     * This ability is used to allow queries against both features and and non spatial data
173     * (such as record) and to express constraints on permissable data values.
174     *
175     * @param  object  the object (often a {@link Feature} instance) to evaluate.
176     * @return {@code true} if the test(s) are passed for the provided object.
177     * @throws NullPointerException if {@code object} is null.
178     * @throws InvalidFilterValueException if the filter cannot be applied on the given object.
179     */
180    @Override
181    boolean test(R object) throws InvalidFilterValueException;
182}
